newsitem.title: CANADA: INSTANT VIEW - Canada Oct CPI rises 1.8 pct on year.
newsitem.headline: INSTANT VIEW - Canada Oct CPI rises 1.8 pct on year.

text.p: Following are reactions to a report by Statistics Canada that consumer prices rose 0.2 percent in October, or 1.8 percent year over year.
Economists had forecast, on average, that CPI would rise 0.1 percent in October or 1.5 percent year over year.

MICHAEL GREGORY, AN ECONOMIST AND STRATEGIST WITH LEHMAN BROTHERS: "On balance, it was kind of a mixed result for the market -- a little bit better than expected on one side, a little bit worse than expected on the other, with no implications for Bank of Canada policy. Basically inflation remains very subdued."

DOUG PORTER, SENIOR ECONOMIST WITH NESBITT BURNS: "The headline number is a little bit disappointing given that it's somewhat higher than expectations, but I think the important point here is that excluding food and energy there's still no sign of any underlying inflation pressure whatsoever."

ANDREW SPENCE, SENIOR ECONOMIST WITH DEUTSCHE MORGAN GRENFELL: "The increase in energy prices drove up the all items rate higher than expected to a year-over-year rate of 1.8 percent. However I have to admit that with core inflation unchanged in the month, disinflation pressures seem to be a little more intense than I'd anticipated.
"I think so long as the exchange rate looks a little bit unsteady here there's no implication for the immediate conduct of (Bank of Canada) policy from this report."
